All letters intended for publication
must be concise, written in ink on
regular letter size paper, on one side
only.
No attention will be paid to anonymous letters, but names signed as an
evidence of good faith will not be
printed if request is made that they be
omitted.
The publication of a letter Is not to
be taken as an indorsement of its views
by the "News-Letter," which invites the
freest discussion of matters of general
interest.

HOMEWOOD, BALTIMORE, MD., NOVEMBER 18, 1924

Dear Sir:
That a Hopkins man should
take delight in ridiculing some of
the most austere organizations on
the campus, and at the same time
defend one which, in its plan, is
a commendable, but is not to be
cOnsidered a part of that group of
organizations which strive to benefit the university as a whole, is a
deplorable circumstance. What
ironic sentiment could have motivated "Another Inactive" the
writer can scarcely imagine unless
it was the ever present desire to
fill space with erroneous, blasphemous, and truly unnecessary
words. Why do these bodies,
namely, Sigma Chi Beta, Pi Delta
Epsilon, Sigma Upsilon and
others, exist? For that matter,
how is the existence of the British
monarch justified? The answer is
the same for both. Their existence
is justified by the dignity and formality which they lend to their
respective institutions, the king to
his nation, and the society to the
Johns Hopkins University.
Mr. "Another Inactive," didn't
you forget that side of the matter?
D. BELL.
POOR BAND!

gor Young .Men
There is nothing like a

STETSON
OST young men today
know theimportance of
looking fit. Good appearance counts much
in the game of life. The young
man who dresses with taste has
a decided advantage.
But—it is surprising how little
thought the average man gives
to his hat. It is his crown, yet he
seems to stop dressing at the neck.
Be careful in your selection of
your headwear. When you buy a
hat, select a Stetson. Its style is
right,its quality means long wear.

HOMEWOOD, BALTIMORE, MD., NOVEMBER 18, 1924

Dear Sir:
That a Hopkins man should
take delight in ridiculing some of
the most austere organizations on
the campus, and at the same time
defend one which, in its plan, is
a commendable, but is not to be
cOnsidered a part of that group of
organizations which strive to benefit the university as a whole, is a
deplorable circumstance. What
ironic sentiment could have motivated "Another Inactive" the
writer can scarcely imagine unless
it was the ever present desire to
fill space with erroneous, blasphemous, and truly unnecessary
words. Why do these bodies,
namely, Sigma Chi Beta, Pi Delta
Epsilon, Sigma Upsilon and
others, exist? For that matter,
how is the existence of the British
monarch justified? The answer is
the same for both. Their existence
is justified by the dignity and formality which they lend to their
respective institutions, the king to
his nation, and the society to the
Johns Hopkins University.
Mr. "Another Inactive," didn't
you forget that side of the matter?
D. BELL.
POOR BAND!

gor Young .Men
There is nothing like a

STETSON
OST young men today
know theimportance of
looking fit. Good appearance counts much
in the game of life. The young
man who dresses with taste has
a decided advantage.
But—it is surprising how little
thought the average man gives
to his hat. It is his crown, yet he
seems to stop dressing at the neck.
Be careful in your selection of
your headwear. When you buy a
hat, select a Stetson. Its style is
right,its quality means long wear.
